file.name: hyperledger.pdf
file.title: Ethereum Virtual Machine and Execution Environment Overview.pdf

text: thanks for the ethereum slide! If my understanding is correct in ethereum the result of a function is executed when someone mines the block and verified by the nodes. What then happens if the function result is non-deterministic? Will it result in fork?

<@U0V35HWHW>: The Ethereum Virtual Machine is completely deterministic; reviewing <https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T0J024XGA-F14HDLYKB/hyperledger.pdf> see last 2 points:
EVM Requirements
● Small code size (so that very many contracts from
many users can be stored by one node)
● VM security designed around running untrusted
code from arbitrary parties
● Multiple implementations (for cross-checking, and
to mitigate developer centralization in the public
chain)
● Perfect determinism (for consensus)
● Infinite loop resistance
– This itself must be accomplished perfectly
deterministically; timeouts are a no-go

file.name: hyperledger.pdf
file.title: Ethereum Virtual Machine and Execution Environment Overview.pdf

text:
<!channel>: Hi, I cautiously use at-channel, and I wonder if the hyperledger project is losing focus.
At an IBM presentation yesterday, a good analogy was presented between the rails and the train.
It looks like the discussions here have been about trains instead of the rails.  For example, details such as UTXOs, chaincode, etc are at the train level, instead of the rails level.  They are helpful, but shouldn't the focus be on defining on the HLTP, then anyone can build trains that go on those rails.  (Right now the discussions look like how to jam everyone's trains together.)

If HLTP isn't clear, a starting point is given by the name itself: transport protocol.  ("HLTP" may be inaccurate itself, but a good reminder about the rails.)
Here's an example:
<https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/libp2p-Whitepaper>
<https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/rlpx.md>
<https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/%C3%90%CE%9EVp2p-Wire-Protocol>

Is the project focusing on HLTP?  If not, why isn't it focusing on the rails?

Also, my colleague <@U0NVCMVT2> who has familiarity with IPFS development, suggested that the IPFS approach could be a good example of focusing on the rails:
<https://github.com/ipfs/specs>

<@U0MRVA8R4>: I agree with your opinion about the rails and trains. After all, we are too technical for now IMO. We need set the standard and benchmark of API, architecture, performance, security, audit, monitoring and etc before we write the code. Of cause the obc and sawtooth are good reference, but we really need a common agreement regarding what is a real industry level blockchain and what kinds of KPI we need.
This is meant to be the task performed by the Arch WG and Identity WG
Although this can be an iterative process. For example bit coin was born from a short introduction and a reference implementation the properties emerged as the system grew.

<!channel>: I'm not sure who is the correct person to reach out to. I was just approached by a conference organizer who asked to get a representative from hyperledger to speak at his conference. Who might that be? Its called Distributed Trade its June 14th in St Louis <https://godistributed.com/trade/>   The focus is on blockchain applications in financial services and trade networks (supply chain mgmt, inventory auditing, cross-border payments, etc

attachments.text: The weekly blockchain technology report covering enterprise-level blockchain applications: financial services, global trade, healthcare, identity, and more.

text:
HIP : Java Chaincode support for Hyperledger Fabric.  Pl. review IBM-DTCC's  joint proposal 
(<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZBRO0X6OAQXKaq3_SjIgZ6uQ_eSFyglex-h2eQ8-H_o/edit?usp=sharing>)  before our TSC meeting
<!channel>: pls review <@U0P2R5BEZ> HIP before this week’s TSC so that we can discuss

I’m not allowed to add comments to the document, so I’ll comment here.  The proposal looks OK, but the timing is poor. If there is a plan to create a fabric 1.0 release in June, then I would prefer to see our core teams focussed on bug fixes, documentation and other critical issues, rather than be distracted by a new project. If I had a vote it would be to defer this until after the fabric 1.0 release.

<@U0N1D1UAE>: well, I don;t know about 1.0 but a release yes… this is why on the fabric project call, I suggested that we need to have a plan for how we work towards the release… do we maintain a dev branch where we allow continued progress on new features (such as this) while we focus on bug squashing and cleanup etc on the master branch, etc.
I don’t think we need to defer
more like fabric 0.n is what I was thinking where n is in the range 1-9

If you are interested in attending this session, please indicated your availability as soon as possible.  We will get this scheduled tomorrow based on responses.

text: <!channel>: I just canceled tomorrow’s TSC call due to light agenda and a conflict
requesting that the WG leads each take a couple minutes to send out a summary update

The "Immersion into Gerrit" session hosted by the Linux Foundation has been scheduled for Tuesday, June 7th at 9:00am PT.

1)  You can join the call at:

<https://www.gotomeeting.com/join/739021541>
United States (toll-free): 1 877 309 2073
United States: <tel:+1(571)317-3129|+1 (571) 317-3129>
Access Code: 739-021-541

2)  If you are planning to attend, please set up an account at <https://www.zephyrproject.org/doc/contribute/gerrit_accounts.html> (ignore the fact that this is for the Zephyr Project, the process is the same, and it has been documented well here).  You will need to log in to <http://gerrit.hyperledger.org|gerrit.hyperledger.org>.  Once you have signed up, please send your account name to <mailto:rjones@linuxfoundation.org|rjones@linuxfoundation.org>.

3)  Lastly, please send your code review workflow questions to Ry Jones <mailto:rjones@linuxfoundation.org|rjones@linuxfoundation.org> in advance.

If you would like to be directly added to the meeting invite, please send a note to <mailto:tbenzies@linuxfoundation.org|tbenzies@linuxfoundation.org> to be added.
<@U0KM61BCP>: not sure you were planning on going through the chaintool HIP this week or not, but I just realized I have a conflict with a thing at my kids school tomorrow and cant make it
but am available next week or whatever works for the TSX
I can’t make the call tomorrow (so sorry)
personal conflict…ok to push to next week instead ?
no problem, we’ll push it to next week
ok, thank you very much for accommodating
just so I am prepared, would the TSC like any kind of presentation, etc, or is whats available enough?
(not a problem either way, just want to make sure I am prepared)
either way is fine, we’ve seen both from other project proposals — whatever you feel is necessary to adequately communicate what your proposal is
<@U0KM61BCP>: do we have an agenda for tomorrow

The Virtual Hackathon will kick-off tomorrow at 10:00am ET.  Dan Middleton has graciously agreed to help kick off the discussion tomorrow morning.  We have a straw-man agenda here (<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ROq44KpxuelkOp8GpceFNcv8K6XfWdaOnknzBk73OMc/edit>) that lists the various call-in details, some proposed topics, etc.  We expect participation from the Community in identifying interesting topics to work on and identifying leaders to drive forward various efforts.  Much like the other Hackathons, this will be run in unconference format.  Please feel free to add comments and suggestions to the Google doc referenced above.
reminder:  virtual hackathon kick-off in 30 min (at 10am ET):  <https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/meetings/join?uuid=M3JYT2WHEKIAVJ31HDKHCY4GSV-9VIB>
<@U0J038AJK>: <@U0KM61BCP> am I on the agenda today?
great call.  since we didn't get to the committee reports (unless I missed that), perhaps the committees could report via email to the tsc list?
Thank you all for the opportunity to present and the feedback
if sep-repo-but-fabric-specific is the direction we want to go, proposal is create hyperledger/fabric-chaintool
This is actually easier for me than merging into fabric/tools/chaintool anyway, as then I don’t need to refactor the doc layout (I just need to remove references to “proposal” etc)

<@U0KM61BCP>, tsc in general: <@U0VKPD6A2> has asked to replace Patrick Holmes as the maintainer for the Sawtooth-* repos. How is that handled? In my other project that would require a vote, but I’m unsure of how governance works on HYP

well, it was Intel’s choice to name it’s maintainers… I don’t think that they ever named anyone else, so seems ok to me that Dan succeed Patrick… however, I would advocate that a healthy project have at least two maintainers and likely 3 so that this is not ever a problem
what is the proper documentation for this? Do we need someone else from Intel to vouch for this change?
looking just now, the people that are maintainers: <@U0Z5FGD0V> and Shawn T Amundson
Patrick Holmes isn’t on the list we use today

Shawn and rbuysse are accurate.  Besides me (dcmiddle) you can add Cian Montgomery (cintel) and then we should be above water on maintainers.  We will of course be happy to add more maintainers esp. those outside of intel.
I’ve invited cintel and dcmiddle to the management group
I implore you to turn on two factor auth, I notice none of the Intel maintainers have TFA turned on

thanks, that was an old msg though ;)
I'll be on the call today
does <@U12J2D15H> have commit rights to <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/blockchain-explorer> ? I don’t see anything in the TSC notes
or, rather, is <@U12J2D15H> supposed to have commit rights

Hi <@U0UHG4VP1> here's the list from the proposal: "The following individuals would be the initial set of maintainers for the project: Satheesh Kathamuthu, Mahesh Gutala, David Huffman, and Peter Schwarz"
Do we have an agenda for tomorrow?
<@U0VKPD6A2> Todd sent an agenda to the list
I thought the wiki was going to support markdown, I apparently missed something

I have a request from DTCC to add another committer to blockchain-explorer. Should I ask them to send email to the TSC to get it on the agenda for next week, or is getting email agreement from the other committers enough?
fwiw, we manage it on fabric by a maintainer submitting a patch to the maintainers.md file
and then the gerrit review of the change serves as the vote
the only real flaw there is that the rules state N/2+2, but because we use gerrit it technically allows 2+2
ghaskins: I was wondering about that (requiring n/2+1)
im not sure gerrit is flexible enough to allow different rules for a specific file though
you might need to create “fabric-maintainers” and “blockchain-explorer-maintainers” , etc, repo to do that
but if you have a way, but all means
We manage the fabric manually but yes, the documented rule is n/2+1
OK. I’ll send email to the three committers and as long as two of them say yes, I’ll add the new committer to b-e

As a reminder, we will be hosting our first European Hackfest (October 3-4) in Amsterdam (this is the Monday following Sibos).  If you are planning to attend, please register at your earliest convenience.  <https://www.regonline.com/hyperledgerhackfestoctober2016>

In addition, we'll be co-sponsoring a large Hackathon at ABN-AMRO's offices nearby over that weekend (October 1-2).  <https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hyperledger-hackathon-tickets-26798489002>

attachments.title: Hyperledger Hackathon
attachments.text: Dear hackers and blockchain lovers, ABN AMRO, together with IBM, Holland FinTech and Linux Foundation are happy to announce the first Hyperledger Hackathon on the 1st-2nd of October in Amsterdam. All developers, hackers, tech students, local and international blockchain community and FinTech companies are welcome to join us to the first 36 hours gathering, focused on the Hyperledger technology.An amazing opportunity to showcase your skills, learn from like-minded mentors and experts and most of all have fun while making awesome stuff.Are you in? If so, be sure to pre-book your ticket.You can register both asHacker: Team of max 6 people or as a single individual (we will assign you a team later on or fill up your group with the missing team member)Visitor: come and have a look around on what these brightful minds are working on Awesome prices for the winning teams: 110k worth of  Bluemix license credits topped up with cool gadgets in the spirit of Virtual Reality Headsets, mini 3d Printers, and drones.More information about the full agenda and details about the different challenges will come closer to the event. Looking forward to meet you in October!

if it didn’t originate with me as organizer, it is not valid

call is canceled this week, right
I was just informed the plugins for the wiki have been installed. I'm not in a position to test them but if there are any issues please let me know.
If anyone knows the Slack ID of the gentleman that proposed the plugins, let me know (or let him know the plugins are installed)
<@U0UHG4VP1> I had asked about it on the TSC call today, if that is what you are talking about
I can respond on the original thread
There was a gentleman that did a partial conversion and sent in a list of proposed plugins.
figured there was a chance you didnt know my voice yet :wink:
but yeah, i wasnt the one who proposed it, just asked about status
I see the little bars bouncing up and down when you talk :)
Given the limitations of Slack, we are evaluating moving to Discourse as an alternative.  As such, if you have not already, please create an account at check out <http://discuss.hyperledger.org/>.
<@U0J038AJK> how come this requires a different login? will this eventually use the LF id?
<@U0P2GSA8Z> I created/reused the same LF id (just created one with the exact same name)
[But I did need to create one]
I understand that's a possibility but that's not the same :slightly_smiling_face:
You are right. That’s not the same, no. I think (guess) these are different systems.
I don’t know what the particulars are for why this isn’t using the LFID directly
<@U0P2GSA8Z> I’m checking with LF IT team to get an answer on what is possible.
it's not a big deal but it's surprising given that so far all the systems have been brought up within LF's single sign-on
Agree with Arnaud--it would be very nice if this uses the LF sign-on.
assuming the community is happy with discourse as a platform, when we moved to a paid version (not expensive) we can use a plugin so that folks can use their LFID
unfortunately, we can’t do that with the test instance
but, it is possible when we move to paid
and we can use email responses to post?
I’m talking with <@U115YGEH1> about setting up repos for iroha. they’re proposing five repos, mirroring the github repos. does the tsc want this, or does the tsc want one combined repo?
as part of the import, you’ll have to squash the repos, which is why I ask

The repositories we were considering are as follows:

- <http://github.com/hyperledger/iroha|github.com/hyperledger/iroha>
- <http://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-docs|github.com/hyperledger/iroha-docs>
- <http://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-ios|github.com/hyperledger/iroha-ios>
- <http://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-android|github.com/hyperledger/iroha-android>
- <http://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-javascript|github.com/hyperledger/iroha-javascript>

/iroha-docs could be merged into /iroha. However, it probably makes sense to keep the iOS/Android/JavaScript as separate projects, as each will need their own test frameworks.
the new repos would be on <http://gerrit.hyperledger.org|gerrit.hyperledger.org>

Yes, that is another point that I would like to discuss. My understanding is that Gerrit is used mainly to handle the developer certificate of origin (DCO) acceptance. It seems that with some dev work, we can program a  git hook for either github or circle CI to execute on pull requests. Given the opportunity, I think that is the preferred option for us, so I would like to know if we are allowed to explore that possibility, as we would prefer to stay on github.
that is a governance issue I can’t address.
Okay, so what is the best way to proceed?
<@U115YGEH1> I’m looking for input from the tsc (members in this channel)
<@U0UHG4VP1> That sounds good. Thanks for the support
BTW, this is one of the options we are thinking about: <https://www.clahub.com/>
My take: i have no problem with multiple repos
regarding gerrit vs github, I think its more than just DCO verification on PRs, GH allows members with enough privileges to bypass the process that gerrit locks down
I think my preference would be to strive to be uniform here
that said, we already have sawtooth-lake and chaintool that operate outside of gerrit
though my take is, this is inertia, not policy
at least that is the case with chaintool
it was in GH before gerrit was an option, and I just havent gone through the push-up of moving it over
<@U0KPFAZNF>: I had forgotten about the direct push issue, I guess I haven’t been awake long enough today :slightly_smiling_face:
Force push to master can and should be disabled
It isn't a force push though
If you are an owner you can push a local change directly and it's merged
I need guidance from the TSC on how to move forward.
Is there documentation explaining what the required process is and what kind of features of git should not be allowed?

<@U115YGEH1> I propose transferring the existing repos under <https://github.com/soramitsu> for iroha (it looks like there isn’t a distinct docs repo). the process is two steps: you would need to transfer them to me - <mailto:rjones@linuxfoundation.org|rjones@linuxfoundation.org> - and then I will transfer them to hyperledger.

attachments.title: ソラミツ
attachments.text: Soramitsu, the Japanese digital identity company using blockchain technology. Proposor of Iroha (<http://iroha.tech>), a simple distributed ledger.

text: <@U115YGEH1> this would mean, though, that you have DCOs for all existing code. is that true?
other members of the channel: this is essentially what we did with the Sawtooth Lake contributions IIRC.
I know that is how we handled chaintool
did we decide if pure GH is fine going forward?
no, we have not decided. The decision is to unblock iroha right now and await consensus on how exactly to onboard new projects.
I think you’re right, it was chaintool that we transferred in that way
<@U0UHG4VP1>: yes, we have DCOs for all the source
How would you like to proceed?
If someone could approve my post to the moderated TSC list ahead of the 1pm ET call in the next 10 minutes, that would be much appreciated
I can't seem to get on the call, is it just me?
oh, I'm an hour off, never mind :slightly_smiling_face:
Please note there will be rolling outages in LF infra in general, and HLP infra specifically, as we roll out the Dirty COW mitigations today.

<@U0Z41KY5V> would like to have a distinct project in JIRA to make administration of the python SDK project easier. specifically, this would let me make him an administrator of his project and run his sprints etc distinct from the fabric sprints. right now he can't create and edit sprints, for instance.

I don't want to do this willy nilly - if there is a reason to have all of the fabric projects on one cadence with <@U0KM61BCP> as the only admin, that's OK. in that case, though, I would propose granting project leads administrator privileges on the overall project (FAB in this case)
<@U0UHG4VP1> clear namespace is important too as Sawtooth has a python sdk as well.
good point… as for admin rights… I thought we did have the leads with privs… no?

I didn't distinguish JIRA projects from Hyperledger projects. The question is: do we make HYP FAB-PY-SDK a distinct JIRA project, or add the HYP FAB-PY-SDK leads as admins to the overall JIRA FAB project?
ah, so is the py-sdk part of FAB now or no?
<@U0KM61BCP> <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/fabric-sdk-py> is a a Fabric SDK in python, so sort of?
<@U1KDHJT6H>: <@U13TWBRBL> thoughts? seems like we should not confuse things by having independent projects for java and python (etc) but include in fab
cbf: right now in JIRA the py-sdk team is unable to create and start sprints and the like. that's the hangup
as far as I can tell, all of the creation permissions are project based.

We have secured a venue for the December Hackfest in New York (Manhattan) for December 5th & 6th.  Please register at your earliest convenience.
<https://www.regonline.com/hyperledgerhackfestdecember2016>
trying to plan my trip to NYC, is there an agenda for Dec 7&8 or at least a start and end times
<@U37P9822X> I have not seen an agenda published for the 7th and 8th yet
yeah thats why I was curious
I think the invite solicited topics and I gather those are getting prioritized now. Additionally there will be project updates on the 8th.
just as a reminder, the agenda for the hackfest is posted here: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iokahBpG7U8TuYn-HmAUCfzLsbq-5L1zW6oWe1ymuv4/edit>

Gitter will have the same issues as slack

no, nothing to add, thanks. just curious what to prep for.

FYI — Hyperledger is looking to hire 4 full-time roles.  Details at: <https://www.hyperledger.org/uncategorized/2017/01/10/help-shape-the-future-of-blockchain-join-the-hyperledger-team>

<@U0Z41KY5V> on the TSC call just now, <@U0TH5GUQ6> said there is a slight preference for someone in SFO, NYC, or London, but the very strong preference is for good people for the roles. I do know LF has employees in Australia and Japan, and probably other places as well that I'm unaware of

oh, sorry, I didn't see you on there. Glad you could make the call

Hi everybody - fyi: I wrote up some thoughts on Digital Asset's GSL paper from last year here:  <https://gendal.me/2017/01/24/towards-deeper-collaboration-in-distributed-ledgers-thoughts-on-digital-assets-global-synchronisation-log/>

attachments.title: Towards Deeper Collaboration in Distributed Ledgers: Thoughts on Digital Asset’s Global Synchronisation Log
attachments.text:
It’s now almost two months since we open-sourced Corda and I’m delighted by the reception it has received. In our rapidly growing community, we’re already seeing new users grow into leaders who help other newcomers get to grips with the platform.
And I am amazed by the number of inbound messages from users who have been impressed by the quality of Corda’s design and codebase – and who are already building significant applications and products on top of it. Indeed, as I write this, one of our member banks is running a global hackathon, with over 150 of their developers building on Corda and I’ve just returned from our Asia Members’ Conference in Hong Kong, where I sat through so many presentations about Corda projects I didn’t even know were happening…
If you’re not already on our Slack or participating in our discussion forum, you’re missing out!
But one additional benefit from delivering on our commitment to make Corda Open Source is that it means we can explore opportunities to collaborate with peers, competitors and partners across the ecosystem: identifying areas where our visions are aligned, where we see things the same way and where we might be able to reuse rather than needlessly reinvent.
A good example of the potential for firms who some might see as competitors (but who actually aren’t…) to collaborate was provided late last year in the form of an excellent whitepaper from Digital Asset: The Global Synchronization Log.  The paper helps clarify some really important aspects of distributed ledger design and shows a really deep understanding of the tradeoffs that are inherent in the design of these platforms.
The first time I read the paper, I was struck by how closely our two firms’ visions for DLT are aligned. As Mike Hearn has written, there are two fundamentally different ways to design a DLT –“UTXO” or “replicated virtual machine” – and it was very encouraging when I realised that our two firms, completely independently, had both concluded that the correct architecture for a significant range of important financial services use-cases is the UTXO model.
This bears repeating: two firms who, in R3’s case, had worked with a huge consortium of financial institutions on a groundbreaking year-long Architecture Working Group and, in the case of Digital Asset, had begun delivery of implementations for clients, had reached extremely similar conclusions about what the “correct” architecture should look like.
But, in reading the paper, it was also clear that we had made some different decisions, too.  And the interesting thing is that the differences are almost all related to choices we’d made about acceptable tradeoffs.  As I’ve often written, there are no perfect solutions in DLT; just tradeoffs. But I will also freely admit that we made some additions to Corda’s technical vision in the light of the paper!
So it’s time, I thought, to share my thoughts on what I think are the key points in the paper and outline how I think Corda could be a perfect way to implement the concept.
What is the Global Synchronisation Log?
At the heart of this space is a beguilingly simple vision:
DLT allows me to build systems where “I know that what I see is what you see”
That is: if a computer system that I own and run and which exists to serve my needs tells me something about a deal you and I have done, I want to know that the system you’re looking at, that you own and run and which exists to serve your needs, is telling you the same thing.
Before Bitcoin and blockchains and Distributed Ledger Technology there were only two ways of doing this, neither of them perfect:  1) we could build a centralised infrastructure and just agree to agree that whatever they say is the truth… consensus by authority, if you like or 2) we could build our own systems and then spend all our lives checking that they had come to the same conclusion about everything… consensus by reconciliation.
Bitcoin and the systems it inspired showed us there was a third way:  we could use advances in cryptography, consensus algorithms and other technologies to give ourselves near total assurance that our systems were in sync without having to employ armies of people to check.
But there was a problem… and this problem is at the absolute heart of everything that’s going on in the DLT space today: the solution invented by Bitcoin and refined through subsequent systems depends on all data being shared with all parties.  So you gain something amazing on one hand: an end to errors, duplication, inconsistency and associated risk. But, on the other hand, you create a privacy nightmare and a system that goes slower the more things you use it for.
This is precisely the conundrum that motivated the invention and development of Corda. We decomposed the building blocks of existing blockchain platforms and reassembled them in the light of the different threat-model we have, the different use-cases and different tradeoffs we are prepared to accept.
One of the key insights in our work was that, for our scenarios, we can separate transaction verification from the question of whether two verified transactions conflict with each other. I wrote about this when we first announced Corda in April last year.
We think the question of transaction verification should be down to the transaction participants: if one of them pretends that their smart contract produced a different answer to what it actually did then we’ll deal with it out-of-band; it’s a permissioned system and we know who they are…   They gain nothing by playing games like that.
But the question of which transactions actually get confirmed is a question for an independent observer; we need somebody we all trust to choose between two equally valid but conflicting transactions. At R3, we call this observer a notary but that’s just the name we use to generalise the role performed by miners in a traditional blockchain.
In so doing, we addressed many of the privacy and scalability issues of other platforms at a stroke.
But it’s a tradeoff, of course.  Because there’s something that a full public blockchain gives you that this approach doesn’t. Both approaches assure you that only valid transactions can get confirmed, but a full public blockchain also ensures that everybody gets to know when this happens.
But, of course, a traditional blockchain does this by using full broadcast, in the clear, of pretty much everything that happens. A privacy and scalability disaster.
So we had some very heated debates when we designed Corda about which tradeoffs were acceptable and which ones were not. And the GSL paper touches on all of them really succinctly.
Two of the more important debates were as follows:
If I send a full transaction to a notary (think ‘miner’ in a traditional blockchain), that could be a privacy leak: the notary gets to see all the data in the transaction. But if I only send the pieces of the transaction that the notary actually needs to see in order to decide transaction ordering then I could execute a “denial of state” attack by having the notary confirm an invalid transaction that “consumes” an input and stops a valid transaction from subsequently being confirmed.
If I send a transaction to a notary, how does it know which other parties to inform? I could execute an attack whereby I get a transaction confirmed but the other side doesn’t learn about it… that might allow me to selectively choose not to reveal it if it so suits me.
In Corda, we made the following observations. We said:
The “notary privacy versus denial-of-state” question is one that sh…
attachments.fallback: Richard Gendal Brown Link: Towards Deeper Collaboration in Distributed Ledgers: Thoughts on Digital Asset’s Global Synchronisation Log
